description: Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25."

Original: Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25."

Update: "The Committee for Religious Affairs with the Tajik government has lifted the ban introduced at the beginning of March on joint prayers in mosques," on March 19. UPDATE: Originally mosques were asked to suspend Friday prayers and other gatherings, now this has been lifted. "The Committee for Religious Affairs with the Tajik government has lifted the ban introduced at the beginning of March on joint prayers in mosques."
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25." The Committee for Religion and the Ordering of Traditions and Rites of Tajikistan has allowed public prayer in mosques of the country since March 20. UPDATE: The original restriction in regards to public gatherings in mosques which was set on March 4 has been lifted.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In Tajikistan "The Dushanbe city municipality said that 'all mass festivities dedicated to the Day of the Capital will be suspended in Dushanbe with the aim of preventing the spread of the coronavirus [Covid-19] and protecting people's health." This Day of the Capital is on April 18.

Tajikistan asks mosques "to suspend public gatherings, including Friday prayers but excluding burial rites" on March 4. Additionally, they are "cancelling traditional public festivities related to the Nowruz holiday, or Persian New Year, celebrated from March 21-25."
On March 4, this restriction was cancelled, but on April 18 all mosques were closed again to prevent mass prayers due to upcoming Ramadan. UPDATE: Mosques that were reopened on March 20 (after initially closed for public gatherings on March 4) were closed again on April 18.
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: As of April 27, non-Muslim religious organizations and churches in Tajikistan are temporarily closed to parishioners until May 10.
